Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

__Text Message__
__Message:__ No I only went two times because they were not going to treat me for the injuries I really had and the guy that I worked for the owner of the truck was keeping me out of town or out so late in the evening working I had trouble from day one being able to get to my appointments so his lawyer that I had started out with I truly believe had only his ( my boss / owner of the truck) interest in mind and he ( the lawyer) told me since I had only went two times he had released me from his representation all in one week I had no transportation and still don't and I really didn't know anything about the way things are handled on going to and from the doctors as far as I could have use money provided by the insurance company to give me a ride back and forth and believe me there was no one telling me nor advising me on the issue plus I was so worried about him firing me because he kept on complaining about his insurance was going to go up because of me and I was not even at fault and the ot
__Date and Time:__ 2023-11-14 
__From Number:__ +15022956274 
__To Number:__ +15023579975
__Direction:__ Inbound
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on November 14, 2023 with Douglas Livers regarding a motor vehicle accident. The contact was an inbound text message from +15022956274 to +15023579975.

In the message, Livers explains that he only attended two appointments because he believes they would not treat him for the injuries he actually had. He says the man he worked for—the owner of the truck—was keeping him out of town or working late in the evenings, which made it difficult from day one to get to his appointments. He states that the lawyer he began with seemed to have only the boss’s interests in mind and told him that because he had only gone two times, the lawyer had released him from representation. He notes that within that same week he had no transportation and still does not, and he admits he did not know anything about how things are handled for going to and from the doctors. He mentions that he could have used money provided by the insurance company to arrange rides back and forth, but there was no one telling him or advising him on this issue. Additionally, he was worried about being fired because the boss continually complained that his insurance would go up because of him, even though he asserts he was not at fault. The message ends with the fragment “and the ot.”
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

Douglas Livers is the client in the case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. On November 14, 2023, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm sent a message to the file noting that a letter of representation and a copy of the police report were attached. The message was followed by Jessa’s signature block for Whaley Law Firm, including her phone number (502) 357-9975 and fax number (502) 364-9363.

On November 15, 2023, Jessa forwarded to the file an email from Harold Dorman regarding the representation. In his reply, Dorman stated that, after reviewing the claim setup under policy FDCLK8, the vehicle and driver shown on the police report are not listed on that policy, which has an inception date of 06/12/23, a date that is after the 01/19/23 date of loss. He noted that once approved, a no coverage letter would be sent. Dorman also searched Root’s records for the root policy number shown on the police report, C6LJQR, and found that a claim had been opened with claim number QMJF78KY. The handling adjuster for that claim is Angela Casey, whose telephone number is 380-235-7317 and whose email address is angela.casey@joinroot.com. Dorman stated that it appears there is no coverage under that policy, but advised contacting Ms. Casey to discuss the matter. He concluded his note by inviting any questions or requests for additional information.

The forwarded thread also included a signature block for H. Robert Dorman, Injury Adjuster II at joinroot.com, with the contact number (614) 645-5281, and reiterated Jessa Galosmo’s closing line, All the best, followed by her Whaley Law Firm signature.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. The matter concerns the external claim 0700228547.

On November 28, 2023, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm wrote to Justin Chumbley regarding the case. In her message, she said she had called Dixie Injury and Rehab, and they confirmed the client had received treatment there. However, Dixie Injury and Rehab indicated they have a different Allstate claim number for the same date of loss. Jessa stated that she would call Allstate to seek clarification.

Earlier that same day, Justin had sent a message (dated November 28, 2023 at 12:29 PM, though the time is shown with a question mark in the record) instructing to verify that the correct provider is listed in the medical tab and to ensure the PIP information is correct. The thread then includes an Allstate response to that inquiry.

The Allstate reply, sent at 12:05 PM on November 28, 2023, stated: “There is no file to send as no bills or records have been received. Please let me know if any questions or concerns.” The message was signed by Brittany Carr of Allstate Property and Casualty Insurance Company, with contact details: Phone (713) 277-9437, Fax (608) 373-7383, claims@claims.allstate.com. The email also contained a confidentiality/privacy notice and indicated the unique Conversation ID: FRc720409cc1dc47.

The prior portion of the thread shows Justin’s earlier request to Allstate, dated Monday, November 27, 2023 at 11:38 AM, in which he asked: “Please forward a complete copy of the PIP file for our client, Douglas Livers.” The thread includes Allstate’s responses and signatures, as well as the standard Allstate email footer.

The correspondence concludes with Jessa’s sign-off: “All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm,” followed by her phone number (502) 357-9975 and fax number (502) 364-9363. The record also notes Jessa’s initials on her messages and the ongoing plan to seek clarification from Allstate regarding the claim and provider information.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

From client: Yes this is Doug Livers I just wanted to send a quick message to check in with you and inform you of my medical condition I have recently had a M.R.I. preformed on my left foot and shoulder I will be going to see the Orthopedic next to see about surgery and or rehab they have found a hair line cracked and nerve damage in my foot and might be facing surgery on my shoulder because it is a mess i have been fired for my job because I filed a claim my shoulder is getting to be unbearable my bills are pile up and having a full nights sleep is completely out of the question from the pan in my shoulder I will keep you up dated and a aways I appreciate you all very much hope you all have a wonderful holiday
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on 1-19-2023 with Douglas Livers regarding a motor vehicle accident. In his message, he identifies himself as Doug Livers and states that he wanted to check in and inform us of his medical condition. He reports that he recently had an MRI performed on his left foot and shoulder and that he will be seeing an orthopedic specialist to discuss possible surgery or rehabilitation.

The imaging has shown a hairline crack and nerve damage in the left foot, and there may be shoulder surgery ahead because the shoulder injury is described as a mess. He notes that he has been fired from his job after filing a claim, and that his shoulder pain is becoming unbearable. His bills are piling up, and he is unable to get a full night’s sleep due to the shoulder pain. He says he will keep us updated and expresses his appreciation for the team, concluding with holiday wishes.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

about.relevance: reporting medical condition and treatment plans after motor vehicle accident

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 26, 2024 with Douglas Livers regarding a motor vehicle accident for case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, conducted by Justin.

During the contact, the client described a gap in treatment. He stated he was scared to take time off work for treatment, afraid of losing his job, which he eventually did. He expressed that he had been referred to a chiropractor by attorney Mory. He added that he had been trying to deal with the injury as best as he could, but it eventually hurt too much and he had to get treatment somewhere.

In the case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, involving client Douglas Livers in the matter of Livers v Allstate, an email exchange took place on July 23, 2024 between members of The Whaley Law Firm and TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC. The communication thread centered on obtaining and sharing the Word version of discovery propounded to Allstate.

At 2:54 PM that day, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Ginny Donnell with the Word version attached. In her message, she wrote: “Good afternoon Ginny, Please find the WORD Version Attached. If you need anything else please do not hesitate to contact us directly.” She also added, “Please add Bryce Koon & myself to any future email chains.” Her signature identified her as Sarena M. Tuttle, with the title Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and provided The Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct dial (D: 502-357-9971), office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. She noted that this was a new email address.

The email chain included a prior thread in which Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm forwarded the request. His message, listing his own contact information (Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022), appears as part of the forwarded correspondence that followed Sarena’s message.

Earlier in the thread, Ginny Donnell had sent a message dated July 23, 2024, at about 2:32 PM, with the subject line “Livers v Allstate,” addressed to Aaron Whaley. In that message she asked: “Could your assistant please send me the word version of discovery propounded to Allstate in this case?” Donnell identified herself as the Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson at TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, located at 11507 Main Street, in the Middletown Historic District of Louisville, KY 40243. Her contact details were provided as PH: (502) 245-7474 and FAX: (502) 245-7025, and a website address www.thslaw.co.

The message chain also included standard cautions and disclaimers. Donnell’s email contained a Privileged and Confidential notice stating that the information in the message is Attorney Privileged and Confidential Information intended for the named recipient, and that dissemination, distribution, or copying is prohibited if the reader is not the intended recipient; readers were asked to notify the sender by telephone if the message was received in error and to delete it. It further stated that there is no attorney-client relationship created by sending or receiving email with the firm. The message also included the firm’s acknowledgment of the disclaimer at www.thattorneys.com.

Additionally, the email contained a note referencing IRS Circular 230 warnings: since the document did not include all required tax disclosures, the reader should not rely on any tax advice contained in the document to avoid penalties, and no portion of the document may be used in marketing or promotional materials. The sequence reflects the logistical steps to share the Word version of discovery and to coordinate future communications for the Livers v Allstate matter.

The note references the Douglas Livers MVA filed January 19, 2023, and shows an email exchange dated July 23, 2024, concerning discovery in the case. The email chain involves The Whaley Law Firm and the Louisville firm Travis, Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with the Filevine project address listed for the Douglas Livers MVA matter.

On July 23, 2024, at 4:05 p.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, sent an email to Ginny Donnell (GDonnell@thattorneys.com). In the message, Bryce asked Ginny if she could provide him with a Word copy of the requests, stating, “Could you please provide me with a word copy of these requests if possible?” The email listed Bryce’s contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207. The message was also copied to Aaron Whaley and included the filevine project address for “Douglas Livers MVA 1/19/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address.” The email contained a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer stating the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, not disclose or forward the content, and no privilege is waived by transmission. There is also a note that no attorney-client relationship is established by sending or receiving the email.

Earlier on July 23, 2024, at 3:55 p.m. (time zone noted in the thread), Ginny Donnell responded. In her reply, she wrote, “Please see attached Discovery Propounded to Douglas Livers.” Ginny Donnell identified herself as a Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson of TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, located at 11507 Main Street, Jefferson Marders Building, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243. The firm’s phone number is (502) 245-7474 and the fax number is (502) 245-7025, and their website is www.thslaw.co.

The email from Ginny Donnell also carried the standard Privileged and Confidential notice, indicating that the information in the email is attorney-privileged and confidential and intended only for the named recipient. It warned that dissemination, distribution, or copying is prohibited if the reader is not the intended recipient, and instructed the recipient to notify the sender by telephone and delete the message if received in error. It reaffirmed that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and referenced a disclaimer required by the sending firm’s website.

In addition, the message included the Circular 230 tax-disclosure associated with IRS tax practice, explaining that if the communication does not contain tax advice, the warning may not apply. It noted that the Treasury’s regulations require extensive disclosures for certain tax communications and advised that since the document does not include all such disclosures, the recipient should not rely on any tax advice in the document to avoid penalties, nor should any portion of it be used in marketing or promotional materials.

Fleming stated that AES had received the request for documentation of a lien and that a request had been sent to obtain an audit of the case. She noted that once AES receives the audit results, they would email the documents as attachments and asked to be informed if any additional information was needed. Fleming provided her contact details and added that one can register for a free account online to view activity and make payments on child support at csws.chfs.ky.gov/csws/. The email also included a confidentiality notice indicating the message and any attachments are for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential information; unauthorized review, use, disclosure, or distribution is prohibited, and if you are not the intended recipient, you should destroy all copies and notify the sender. The notice also contained a reminder to contact the sender if there are questions, and included the sender’s email address, Amy.Fleming@ky.gov, and phone number 502-564-2285.

The prior correspondence in the same IV-D case involved Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm. On August 12, 2024, at 3:15 PM, Tuttle sent an email to CHFS DIS CSE CSLN Communication with the subject IV-D 0005568409 Douglas Livers & Theresa Gregory. The body of her email, which carried a caution about PDF attachments potentially linking to malicious sites, stated that this message was a follow-up to a voicemail left moments earlier. Tuttle indicated that her office had been provided a copy of a lien dated February 15, 2023 from Allstate Insurance. She noted, however, that the lien notice listed an expiration date of July 31, 2021. The email further stated that the lien did not include any ledgers and/or supporting documentation. Tuttle requested that the recipient provide an updated payment ledger along with any and all supporting documents retained by their office for immediate review and consideration. She warned that if the requested information was not received within 30 days, they would have to assume the lien had expired and/or been satisfied prior to the request. She closed by inviting any questions and offering to discuss the lien in further detail, and signed with her name, title (Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager), the Whaley Law Firm, and contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details align with the firm’s address and phone lines, and the note highlights a new email address for Sarena Tuttle. The sequence of communications shows an ongoing effort to resolve the lien documentation in connection with the IV-D case involving Douglas Livers and Theresa Gregory.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers.

On August 19, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, sent an email to Amy F. Fleming of the Kentucky Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement, regarding the file labeled “Douglas Livers IVD 5568409.” In her message, she noted that, after reviewing the documents provided, they could only find a payment ledger and did not see any Court Order attached. She requested verification that Mr. Livers was actually court-ordered to make payments and asked for the exact amount ordered, adding that any and all amendments to any orders should be included.

Sarena also provided the firm’s contact information and noted that this was her new email address. Her signature listed The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Amy Fleming replied, at 1:56 PM, “You’re welcome!” and included her own contact information: Amy Fleming, Administrative Enforcement Section Supervisor, Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement, Administrative Enforcement Section, 502-564-2285, and a link to register for a free online account to view activity and make payments at csws.chfs.ky.gov/csws/. Her message also contained a confidentiality notice stating the message and attachments are for the intended recipient and may contain confidential information, with instructions to destroy copies and notify the sender if not the intended recipient.

In a follow-up, Sarena responded at 1:54 PM, stating, “Awesome. Thank you for your assistance. We will review these documents with our client.” Her signature again included The Whaley Law Firm’s address and contact details, and reminded that the email address was new.

Earlier in the thread, at 1:51 PM, Amy Fleming had written: “Good afternoon, Please find attached supporting documents audit completed 8/14/24. If any other information is needed please let us know.” Her signature block appeared with the same organizational details as above, followed by the confidentiality notice.

Overall, the exchange centered on obtaining a court-ordered payment obligation for Douglas Livers, as the records provided only contained a payment ledger rather than a Court Order, and included the attached documents audit completed on 8/14/24. The participants exchanged several brief confirmations and notices about confidentiality and online access.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. This is an email thread concerning Douglas Livers IVD 5568409, with the subject line FW: Douglas Livers IVD 5568409. The exchange involves Amy Fleming of the Kentucky Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement (Administrative Enforcement Section), and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, related to court-ordered child support in the case.

On August 19, 2024, at 1:51 PM, Amy Fleming sent an email noting that she was attaching supporting documents and that an audit had been completed on August 14, 2024. She invited the recipient to contact her if any additional information was needed. Her message included her signature, listing her role as Administrative Enforcement Section Supervisor, contact number 502-564-2285, and a link for online access to view activity and make payments at csws.chfs.ky.gov/csws/. A standard confidentiality notice accompanied the email, stating that the message and any attachments are for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential information, with instructions to destroy copies and notify the sender if not the intended recipient.

At 1:54 PM that day, Sarena Tuttle replied, thanking for the assistance and stating that they would review the documents with their client. Her signature block identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and providing the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), and phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971, O: 502-583-4022 ext 104).

Shortly after, at 1:56 PM, Amy Fleming replied, “You’re welcome!” and again included the standard confidentiality notice along with her CHFS contact information and online access link.

The thread continued at 2:40 PM with Sarena Tuttle writing to Amy Fleming. She commented that, upon review, they only saw a payment ledger and that there did not appear to be a Court Order attached. She requested verification that Mr. Livers was actually court-ordered to make payments and the amount that was ordered, and asked that any and all amendments to any and all orders be included.

In the same thread, the correspondence shows Amy Fleming’s final note in the sequence: "Please find attached copy of Court orders entered." She reiterated her contact details and the online account availability, including the same link to csws.ky.gov. The confidentiality notice was included in this message as well.

Additionally, Sarena’s signature blocks in the exchanged messages reflect the firm’s details and note the new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, for future correspondence.

In summary, the case file contains an initial email from Amy Fleming claiming an attached copy of court orders and referencing an audit completed on 8/14/24, followed by a Whaley Law Firm acknowledgment and intent to review; a subsequent reply confirming the documents would be reviewed; a later follow-up noting that only a payment ledger was present and requesting verification of the court-ordered payments and any amendments; and a final message from Amy asserting that copies of the court orders were attached, along with standard confidentiality language and the online access instructions.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

Re: FW: Douglas Livers IVD 5568409

In August 2024, communications occurred between The Whaley Law Firm and Kentucky Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement, regarding a lien related to Douglas Livers. On August 21, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Amy Fleming of CHFS. She thanked Amy for her assistance and for the copies of the order. Based on the review of the documents submitted, Sarena noted that a motion was allegedly filed on October 2, 2015 by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers. However, the orders provided were not attested by the judge. Consequently, unless other documents could be provided for review, Sarena stated they could not verify that Mr. Livers was actually ordered to pay child support. As a result, she requested the removal of the lien until an actual Court Order could be produced. She asked Amy to submit a notice of lien revocation as soon as possible and/or submit a formal Court Order validating the lien.

Sarena’s signature included her title and contact information: Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to note the new email address.

Earlier, on August 19, 2024, communications were exchanged. At 1:51 PM, Amy Fleming wrote to Sarena that she would be sending a copy of Court orders entered (with her contact details and confidentiality notice). On August 19 at 1:54 PM, Sarena replied: “Awesome. Thank you for your assistance. We will review these documents with our client.” Her message also included her role and contact details and reiterated the new email address.

At 1:56 PM, Amy responded: “You’re welcome!” with her title as Administrative Enforcement Section Supervisor for the Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement, and her phone number (502-564-2285), plus a note that recipients could register for a free account online to view activity and make payments at csws.chfs.ky.gov/csws/, and a confidentiality notice.

At 2:40 PM, Sarena sent another message stating that, upon review, they only saw a payment ledger and there did not appear to be a Court Order attached. She requested verification that Mr. Livers was actually court ordered to make payments and the amount ordered, and asked that any amendments to any orders be included as well.

At 2:53 PM, Amy Fleming replied with a message that included: “Please find attached copy of Court orders entered,” along with her standard signature block and confidentiality notice.

At 2:55 PM, Sarena responded: “Awesome. Thank you so much.”

In a prior thread, on August 19, 2024 around 2:40 PM to 2:55 PM, there was a chain where Sarena reiterated the need for verification of a Court Order and any amendments, while Amy provided attached Court orders in response to that request. The August 21 email from Sarena summarized the substance of these exchanges and reiterated the request for proof of an actual Court Order or an appropriate lien revocation.

Supporting documents referenced in the email chain included an audit of supporting documents completed on August 14, 2024, which Amy had previously attached and noted as available for review. The correspondence also included standard confidentiality notices and contact information typical of the parties’ communications. The Whaley Law Firm’s signature block repeatedly noted Sarena’s role and indicated the new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, in addition to the firm’s Louisville, KY mailing address and phone numbers.

In summary, the core issue communicated across these exchanges is that there was a motion allegedly filed on October 2, 2015 by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers, but the orders provided were not attested by a judge. Because of this, the lien against Douglas Livers could not be verified as valid, and the lien needed to be removed unless a formal Court Order validating the lien could be produced. The parties exchanged copies of Court orders and requested verification of the existence and terms of any court-ordered child support, including any amendments to relevant orders, with the goal of either obtaining a valid Court Order or revoking the lien.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023 involves Douglas Livers and concerns an interstate child support matter identified as IVD 5568409. In August 2024, Amy Fleming of the Kentucky Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement (Administrative Enforcement Section), exchanged a series of emails with Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, regarding court orders connected to a lien and the underlying obligation.

On August 21, 2024 at 7:47 p.m. UTC, Amy Fleming sent Sarena Tuttle a message stating, “Sarena, please find attached order established 12/7/15.” Fleming’s message included her contact information and a confidentially-notice indicating that the message and any attachments were for the sole use of the intended recipient and may contain confidential information; it also directed any unintended recipients to destroy copies and notify the sender. Fleming’s message also reminded that the Kentucky CSWS (Child Support Workstation) site offers free online account registration to view activity and make payments.

Earlier that same day, at 2:44 p.m., Fleming informed Tuttle that the CSE did not have access to the order at that time and that a request had been sent to the Hall of Justice to obtain a copy, noting that the order was set out of a domestic violence order (DVO) and later incorporated into the CI docket; she added that the 10/3/17 order confirms enforcement purposes for the obligation amount along with a retroactive effective date, and she would send a copy once received.

At 2:08 p.m. on August 21, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied to Fleming, thanking her for assistance and the copies of the order. She explained that, based on their review of the submitted documents, they understood a motion had been made on October 2, 2015 by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers. She stated that the provided orders were not attested by the judge, and absent additional documents for review, they could not verify that Mr. Livers was actually ordered to pay child support. Consequently, she said they would have to request removal of the lien until an actual Court Order could be produced, and she asked that Fleming submit a notice of lien revocation as soon as possible and/or submit a formal Court Order validating the lien. Tuttle’s signature block included her new email address, phone numbers, and firm details.

Earlier, at 2:55 p.m. on August 19, 2024, Sarena wrote, “Awesome. Thank you so much,” followed by her standard signature block. At 2:53 p.m. Fleming replied, “Please find attached copy of Court orders entered,” including her contact information and again the confidentially notice. The same day, at 2:40 p.m., Sarena had written to Fleming noting that, upon review, they only saw a payment ledger and no Court Order attached. She requested verification that Mr. Livers was actually court-ordered to make payments and to specify the amount ordered, asking that any amendments to all orders be included.

On August 19, 2024, at 1:56 p.m., Fleming responded, “You’re welcome!” and reiterated the confidentiality statement. Earlier, at 1:54 p.m., Sarena had written to Fleming thanking her for the assistance and indicating they would review the documents with their client.

In sum, the exchange reveals that CHFS located an order described as established on December 7, 2015, and Fleming later indicated that the CSE did not yet have access to the order and was seeking a copy from the Hall of Justice. Fleming also noted a 10/3/17 order related to enforcement and retroactive date, with plans to send the copy when obtained. Tuttle, however, raised concerns that the October 2, 2015 motion by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers was not attested by a judge and that the orders provided were not court-attested, leading to a request to revoke the lien unless a formal court order validating the lien could be produced. The parties also discussed that the only attached material initially appeared to be a payment ledger, not a court order, and that any payment-related order details and amendments needed to be provided for verification.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the communications surrounding the Douglas Livers case (IVD 5568409) in August 2024, as it relates to a child support/ Family Court enforcement matter tied to the client Douglas Livers.

The file begins with a case note dated January 19, 2023, listed as Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, for client Douglas Livers. The subject line referenced is FW: Douglas Livers IVD 5568409. On August 21, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, emailed Amy Fleming of the Kentucky Department for Income Support (CHFS), Administrative Enforcement Section, to acknowledge payment and to request that the Formal Child Support Order be forwarded upon receipt. In her message, Sarena stated: “Thank you. This order covers the period from the date of issuance until the Family Court matter was resolved. Please forward the Formal Child Support Order upon receipt.” Her signature included her contact information and note of her new email address.

Earlier in the day, on August 21, 2024, at approximately 3:47 PM, Amy Fleming replied to Sarena with the information: “Sarena, Please find attached order established 12/7/15.” Fleming’s message also contained her professional title and contact details.

Additionally, a preceding exchange on August 21, 2024 shows that Fleming had informed Sarena that CSE did not currently have access to the order and that a request had been sent to the Hall of Justice to obtain a copy. Fleming noted that the order was set out of a domestic violence order (DVO) and later incorporated into the CI docket; she indicated that the 10/3/17 order confirms enforcement purposes for the obligation amount along with a retroactive effective date, and that she would send a copy once received.

In the interim communications on August 21, 2024, Sarena also conveyed concerns about the sufficiency and attestation of the documents. At approximately 2:08 PM, she wrote that, after reviewing the submitted documents, a motion had been made on October 2, 2015 by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers. She explained that the provided orders were not attested by the judge, and unless additional documents were provided for review, they could not verify that Mr. Livers was actually ordered to pay child support. Consequently, she requested the removal of CHFS’s lien until an actual court order could be produced and asked that notice of lien revocation be submitted promptly, or that a Formal Court Order validating the lien be provided. Her message, like others, included her professional signature block and note about the new email address.

Earlier still, on August 19, 2024, Sarena thanked Amy for the assistance and copies of the order, but noted that, based on the documents submitted, the file only contained a payment ledger with no attached court order. She requested verification that Mr. Livers was actually court-ordered to make payments and asked that any and all amendments to orders be included. Amy responded on August 19 with a message indicating that copies of court orders had been attached, and Sarena again replied later that day with appreciation.

Throughout these exchanges, the participants referenced the need for a formal court order to validate any lien and to confirm the amounts and existence of child support obligations. They also discussed the availability of orders and the process to obtain or validate them, including potential retroactive dates and enforcement purposes noted in orders identified as 10/3/17, and the relationship between DVO-derived orders and CI docket entries.

In sum, the communications reflect ongoing efforts to verify and obtain a Formal Child Support Order for Douglas Livers, ensure that a lien is properly supported by an actual court order, and determine the enforcement period and related retroactive dates. The most recent development in the chain was Amy Fleming’s August 21, 2024 response indicating an attached order dated 12/7/15 and the expectation that the Formal Child Support Order would be forwarded upon receipt.

episodes.natural_language:
Narrative summary of the communications regarding Douglas Livers (IVD 5568409) between The Whaley Law Firm and the Kentucky Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement (CHFS), dated August 19–21, 2024.

The thread opens on August 19, 2024, when Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, contacts Amy Fleming of CHFS after reviewing the case materials. At 2:40 PM, Sarena explains that, based on the submitted documents, they only have a payment ledger and no court order attached. She asks CHFS to provide verification that Mr. Douglas Livers was actually court-ordered to make payments and to specify the amount ordered, requesting that any amendments to orders be included as well. She signs with her office information and notes a new email address.

At 2:53 PM, Amy Fleming responds with a different update, stating, “Please find attached copy of Court orders entered.” Her signature includes her CHFS contact information and confidentiality notice.

Shortly after, at 2:55 PM, Sarena replies, thanking Amy and acknowledging the correspondence. She confirms receipt of the copies and notes appreciation for the assistance.

The next day, August 21, 2024, the exchange continues with more detail about the underlying orders. At 2:08 PM, Sarena writes that a motion was made on October 2, 2015 by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers. She states that the orders provided are not attested by the judge and, unless CHFS can supply additional documents for review, they cannot verify that Mr. Livers was actually ordered to pay child support or the amount ordered. Consequently, she requests removal of CHFS’s lien until an actual court order can be produced and asks CHFS to submit a notice of lien revocation as soon as possible and/or submit a Formal Court Order validating the lien.

At 2:44 PM, Amy responds that CSE does not have access to the order at that time. She explains that a request has been sent to the Hall of Justice to obtain a copy, noting that the order had been set out of a Domestic Violence Order (DVO) and later incorporated into the CI docket. She mentions that the 10/3/2017 order confirms enforcement purposes for the obligation amount along with a retroactive effective date, and she commits to sending a copy once it is received.

At 2:53 PM, Sarena replies again, expressing appreciation for the information but reiterating that, based on the reviewed documents, the October 2, 2015 motion by Wende Raderer on behalf of Theresa Livers is not attested by a judge. She emphasizes that, without an actual Court Order or a formally attested document, they cannot verify that Mr. Livers was ordered to pay child support or determine the amounts. She requests the submission of a lien revocation notice as soon as possible and/or submission of a Formal Court Order validating the lien.

Later that same day, at 3:47 PM, Amy sends another message. She writes, “Sarena, Please find attached order established 12/7/15.” The signature lines again include Amy Fleming’s CHFS contact information and the confidentiality notice.

At 3:54 PM, Sarena replies, confirming receipt of the attached order and stating that the order covers the period from the date of issuance until the Family Court matter was resolved. She asks that, upon receipt, CHFS forward the Formal Child Support Order. She signs with her office details and new email address.

Finally, at 8:00 PM on August 21, 2024, Amy reiterates and attaches the order again, writing, “Please find attached order per request.” Her email signature again provides CHFS contact information and the confidentiality notice, and she invites the recipient to register for a free online account to view activity and make payments on child support.

Throughout the thread, Confidentiality notices appear in the email signatures, indicating that the messages and attachments are for the sole use of the intended recipients and may contain confidential information. The Whaley Law Firm’s communications include the sender’s and recipient’s contact details, including Sarena M. Tuttle’s title and new email address. The CHFS communications include Amy Fleming’s title and contact information, along with the online account registration invitation.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Call Back - He thought Claim was over - Explained that we have a 30 day deadline to Answer the Disc Req but that is not the end of the claim - He felt like it was since he could not answer most of the Disc Req - He explained that the truck he was driving was his employer's vehicle & he was on the way to a job - Once the MVA happened - The employer stressed to him to say he just 'borrowed' the truck & was not on the way to a job site - He further explained the Employer was paying him under the table as well as several others - Employer was pushing him not to say anything about work since Employer is under Contract and does not have proper insurance coverages - Advised I will discuss this Fact w/BK in further detail - May be a WC Claim to Open w/Special Fund for Uninsured Workers

Discussed Medical Treatment - Foot, Broken, Healed - Left Shoulder, Needs Sx, Does not have health Insurance & Cannot afford, Ringing in the Ear Still Present - Unable to lift left shoulder - Does not have a PCP - Dixie & Aptiva are all the providers seen - Shoulder issue was pre-existing but brought into disabling reality by MVA

Client returned to Work for same Employer due to Financial Strain - Employer only working him 1-2 days a week - Feels this is just to keep him from talking about lack of proper insurance 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 22 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. On August 22, 2024, the initial client contact was made with Sarena regarding Douglas Livers and the motor vehicle accident. The client thought the claim was over and was told that there is a 30-day deadline to answer the Discovery Request, but that deadline does not end the claim. He felt the claim was over because he could not answer most of the Discovery Request. He explained that the truck he was driving was his employer's vehicle and he was on the way to a job when the MVA occurred. After the accident, the employer stressed that he should say he had merely borrowed the truck and was not en route to a job site. He further explained that the employer was paying him under the table, as well as several others, and was pushing him not to say anything about work since the employer is under contract and does not have proper insurance coverages. I advised that I would discuss this fact with BK in further detail, and noted that there may be a workers’ compensation claim opened with the Special Fund for Uninsured Workers.

Discussed medical treatment: the client has a foot injury that is broken and has healed; the left shoulder requires surgery but the client cannot afford it due to no health insurance; ringing in the left ear remains present; he is unable to lift the left shoulder; he does not have a primary care physician. Dixie and Aptiva are the providers seen. The shoulder issue was pre-existing but was brought into disabling reality by the motor vehicle accident.

The client returned to work for the same employer due to financial strain, with the employer only scheduling him 1–2 days a week; he feels this is intentional to keep him from discussing the lack of proper insurance.

If any other information is needed please let us know.” The email included the sender’s contact details: Amy Fleming, Amy.Fleming@ky.gov, Administrative Enforcement Section Supervisor, Department for Income Support, Child Support Enforcement, Administrative Enforcement Section, 502-564-2285. It also noted: “You can now register for a free account online to view activity and make payments on your child support at https://csws.chfs.ky.gov/csws/.” NOTICE OF CONFIDENTIALITY: This message, including any attachment(s), is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure, or distribution is strictly prohibited. If you are no the intended recipient, please destroy all copies of the original message and notify the sender immediately.

The motor vehicle accident case Douglas Livers v. Allstate, identified as Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, concerns an incident that occurred on January 19, 2023. The client is Douglas Livers. On September 17, 2024, at 1:08 PM Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, emailed Ginny Donnell of Travis, Herbert & Stempen, PLLC. In her message, she advised that her office and client were available for most of November and invited Ginny to propose starting dates that would work for both offices and the client. She stated that their understanding is that Mrs. Lewis was at fault for the incident but did not have insurance, and they would like to depose Mrs. Lewis at some point. She noted that Mrs. Lewis had not yet responded to the Complaint or the Cross-Complaint, despite service having been obtained in July. The email closed with Sarena’s contact details, including her new email address.

Earlier in the thread, Ginny Donnell, acting as Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson of TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, had asked, in a message dated around 9:44 AM on September 17, 2024, whether counsel could provide dates when their client would be available to give a deposition in November. The message addressed Bryce Whaley and Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm, and it included the law firm’s address at 11507 Main Street, Jefferson Marders Building, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; phone number 502-245-7474 and fax 502-245-7025; website www.thslaw.co. The email was marked Privileged and Confidential, with a warning that, unless otherwise indicated or obvious, the information was attorney privileged and confidential and intended only for the named recipient. It stated that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and included the standard disclaimer that the sender or recipient acknowledges the disclaimer contained on www.thattorneys.com. The message also contained the IRS Circular 230 tax-warning language, explaining that the document does not contain all required tax disclosures and that reliance on any tax advice may be inappropriate for avoiding penalties. The forwarded message concluded with the signature of Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, including his address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022, and his email, Sarena’s counterpart’s contact details.

I asked if she could email a document outlining the client’s benefits, and she said she would send it via email.

Insurance details for this update are: Insurance Type is Personal Injury Protection (PIP) and the Insurance Company is Allstate Insurance. This note was written by Sarena Tuttle.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. The matter is captioned Livers v Allstate.

In a thread related to the Livers v Allstate case, dated September 25, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Ginny Donnell with copies to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. The subject line read “Re: Livers v Allstate.” In the body of the email, Sarena asked, “Good afternoon Ginny, Have you had a chance to select some dates for Mr. Liver's Deposition?” Her contact information was included in the signature, noting the Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the parenthetical reminder “(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).”

Earlier in the conversation, on September 17, 2024, at approximately 1:08 PM, Sarena had written to Ginny noting that The Whaley office and the client were available “most of November” and inviting Ginny to pick starting dates that would work for both offices. She also stated her understanding that Mrs. Lewis was at fault for the incident but did not have insurance, and she indicated a desire to depose Mrs. Lewis as well at some point. She added that Mrs. Lewis had not yet responded to the Complaint and/or Cross-Complaint despite service in July. Sarena signed with her full title and contact details, including again the notice to use the new email address.

Also on September 17, 2024, at about 10:18 AM, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message from Ginny Donnell. The forwarded message, dated September 17, 2024 at 9:44 AM, was from Ginny Donnell and was addressed to Bryce Whaley and Aaron Whaley. In that email, Ginny requested, “Can you please provide dates when your client would be available to give a deposition in November?” The message included Ginny’s professional affiliation as Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson at TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, with their office address at 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, and contact details: PH: (502) 245-7474 and FAX: (502) 245-7025, along with the firm’s website www.thslaw.co.

The Ginny Donnell email also contained standard privilege and confidentiality notices indicating the information was attorney-privileged and confidential, intended for the named recipient, with a warning that dissemination, distribution, or copying by anyone else is prohibited; it stated that no attorney-client relationship is established by sending or receiving email from the firm. It also included IRS Circular 230 tax-disclosure language to the effect that the document does not contain all required tax disclosures and that tax advice should not be relied upon, along with the firm’s disclaimer that sending email does not create an attorney-client relationship. The message concluded with contact details for Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and his phone number 502-583-4022.

In addition to the exchanges above, the original subject line and case context remained anchored to Livers v Allstate, with the matter continuing to involve the deposition scheduling for Douglas Livers in the underlying motor vehicle accident case.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers.

In the matter of Livers v Allstate, a September 2024 email thread shows ongoing discussions about scheduling depositions and the issue of uninsured status. On September 17, 2024, Ginny Donnell, legal assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson of Travis, Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, sent an email to Sarena Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm asking Bryce Whaley and Aaron Whaley to provide dates in November when their client would be available to testify in the Livers v Allstate case. Donnell noted that Ms. Herbert believes the plaintiff bears the burden to prove that the defendant is uninsured and suggested that they probably should hold off a little longer on scheduling the plaintiff’s deposition while they awaited discovery responses. The signature block included the sending attorney’s firm information and standard notices, including Privileged and Confidential statements, a disclaimer that no attorney‑client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and an IRS Circular 230 tax‑advice warning.

Earlier that day, Aaron Whaley forwarded the request to Bryce Whaley and others, and Sarena Tuttle replied later that day: Our office and client are available most of November, so they could start with dates that work best for the opposing side. She indicated their understanding that Mrs. Lewis was at fault for the incident but did not have insurance, and she added that they would like to take Mrs. Lewis’s deposition as well at some point, though Mrs. Lewis had not yet responded to the Complaint or Cross-Complaint despite service having been obtained in July. Tuttle’s signature noted a new email address and included the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky contact information.

On September 25, 2024, Tuttle followed up again, asking Ginny Donnell whether dates had been selected for Mr. Liver’s deposition. The message again referenced the availability for November and included Tuttle’s contact information with the new email address.

Finally, on September 26, 2024 at 18:39:36 UTC, Donnell replied that, from Ms. Herbert’s perspective, the plaintiff bears the burden to prove that the defendant is uninsured. Consequently, she suggested delaying the plaintiff’s deposition a bit longer and informed Whaley that they were still awaiting discovery responses. The email included the same standard Privileged and Confidential notices, the no attorney‑client relationship disclaimer, and the IRS Circular 230 tax warning that appeared in the prior messages.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. This narrative follows the email correspondence regarding the Livers v. Allstate matter, with the subject line Re: Livers v Allstate. The exchange involves counsel from Travis, Herbert & Stempien, PLLC and The Whaley Law Firm, and centers on deposition scheduling and issues of insurance coverage.

On September 17, 2024, at 9:44 a.m., Ginny Donnell, Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson at Travis, Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, asked Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley to provide dates when their client would be available to give a deposition in November. At 10:18 a.m. that same day, Aaron Whaley forwarded Ginny’s request to the appropriate recipients. Later that day, at approximately 1:08 p.m., Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied that their office and client were available for most of November and invited the defense to propose starting dates. She also stated their understanding that Mrs. Lewis was at fault for the incident but did not have insurance, and she noted an interest in deposing Mrs. Lewis as well; however, Mrs. Lewis had not yet responded to the Complaint or Cross-Complaint, despite service having been obtained in July.

On September 25, 2024, at 12:10 p.m., Sarena followed up again, asking Ginny whether dates had been selected for Mr. Livers’ deposition. The next day, September 26, 2024, at around 2:39 p.m., Ginny Donnell responded that, at this point, Ms. Herbert believed the Plaintiff bears the burden to prove the Defendant is uninsured, and therefore suggested delaying scheduling the Plaintiff’s deposition a bit longer while discovery responses were still being sought.

Shortly thereafter, at approximately 2:54 p.m. on September 26, 2024, Sarena sent a reply detailing attachments: a Police Report and a Denial from ROOT verifying that the vehicle owner’s policy was not in effect at the time of the incident. She noted that the policy for the vehicle owner was cancelled on December 29, 2022 and was not reinstated until after the incident.

Earlier on September 26, 2024 at 6:56 p.m. (GMT), Ginny Donnell sent a closing email stating, “Yes, thank you. Ms. Herbert is working on our responses.” This message also included the standard Privileged and Confidential notices, a No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer, and the IRS Circular 230 tax warning requirements, indicating that the information is attorney-privileged and confidential and that dissemination is prohibited if the reader is not the intended recipient.

In summary, the correspondence reveals ongoing negotiation over deposition timing and parties’ availability, a belief by the plaintiff’s side that uninsured status must be proven by the plaintiff, and documentary work confirming that the defendant’s policy was not in effect at the time of the January 19, 2023, motor vehicle incident, with the policy not reinstated until after the incident. The chain also confirms that Ms. Herbert’s team was still awaiting discovery responses when the latest communications occurred.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
The case is Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, concerning Douglas Livers and the matter titled Livers v Allstate. In late September 2024, the Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, sent an email to Ginny Donnell of TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC regarding deposition dates for the Livers v Allstate matter. She noted that, despite a September 17, 2024 office email from Ginny requesting deposition dates, the Whaley Firm had not yet received a response from the opposing side. Tuttle attached a Police Report and a Denial from ROOT showing that the vehicle owner’s policy was not in effect at the time of the incident: specifically, the vehicle owner’s policy was canceled on December 29, 2022 and was not reinstated until after the incident. Tuttle’s message also provided her contact information and included the note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Ginny Donnell responded on September 26, 2024 at approximately 2:39 PM, stating that, at that point, Ms. Herbert believed the plaintiff had the burden to prove that the defendant was uninsured. As a result, she suggested delaying the scheduling of the plaintiff’s deposition and indicated that discovery responses were still being sought. Donnell’s email carried the standard privileged and confidential disclaimers common to communications from TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, and included the firm’s contact information: Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson as the addressees, the firm’s Louisville address at 11507 Main Street, the Jefferson Marders Building in the Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, phone number 502-245-7474, fax 502-245-7025, and the website www.thslaw.co. The message also carried the firm’s “Privileged and Confidential” notice, the disclaimer about no attorney-client relationship, and the IRS Circular 230 warning about tax advice disclosures.

The thread also shows a sequence of prior communications leading up to that date. On September 25, 2024, Sarena Tuttle emailed Ginny Donnell asking whether dates could be selected for Mr. Liver’s deposition, noting that the office and client were available for most of November and that they would want to coordinate dates that worked for the other side as well. In a previous message, dated September 17, 2024 at 1:08 PM, Sarena stated that their office and client were available for most of November and suggested choosing starting dates that would fit the other side’s schedule. She also indicated that their understanding was that Mrs. Lewis was at fault for the incident but did not have insurance, and she expressed a desire to depose Mrs. Lewis as well; however, Mrs. Lewis had not yet responded to the Complaint or Cross-Complaint despite service being obtained in July. The communications include a note that Aaron Whaley forwarded Ginny Donnell’s September 17, 2024 request, which asked for deposition dates in November, and that Donnell’s initial inquiry came from Ginny Donnell on the same date, asking for available dates for a deposition in November.

The email chain includes the usual forwarding and signatures. The Sept. 17 and Sept. 25 messages from Sarena Tuttle contain her Whaley Law Firm contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (502) 357-9971; office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; with a note indicating the email address is new. The Sept. 17, 2024 message also shows the sender’s designation as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager.

In sum, the communications reflect ongoing efforts to schedule depositions related to Livers v Allstate, with a focus on confirming available dates in November, seeking discovery responses, and handling issues related to uninsured status and the insured-party’s timing. The most recent substantive position, as of September 26, 2024, is that Valerie W. Herbert’s office believes the plaintiff bears the burden of proving the defendant’s uninsured status and proposes delaying the plaintiff’s deposition until those issues are resolved, while continuing to pursue any outstanding discovery responses. The attached police report and ROOT denial support the argument that the vehicle owner’s policy was not in effect at the time of the incident, given the policy cancellation on December 29, 2022 and non-reinstatement until after the incident.

__Your Outstanding Discovery Responses__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Douglas Livers [douglivers@gmail.com](mailto:douglivers@gmail.com)
CC: classyangel1984@yahoo.com 
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2024 13:18:25 -0400

Good afternoon Mr. & Mrs. Livers,
 Please find attached the Defense Counsel's Discovery Request sent to
you on July 24, 2024 via USPS & Email. To date we still have not received
your responses. The Discovery Process is an imperative phase of litigation
and we are under deadlines to provide your responses which are now 60+ days
overdue.
 Please answer the following questions, in detail, so that we may
finalize your Discovery Responses before the Defense files a Motion to
Compel and/or seeks penalties for the delayed responses. If you have any
questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in
further detail.

1. Current Occupation
2. Lost Wages Information
3. Are any injuries caused by an aggravation of previous condition
4. Any jobs or tasks he is unable to do
5. Medical providers past 15 years
6. Employers last 10 years
7. Any copies of repair bills or estimates

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

Good morning Douglas,
 Please find attached the Defense Counsel for Allstate Insurance's
Discovery Request propounded to you for your review and response. We
understand the packet can seem quite overwhelming at 1st glance, however,
we are here to assist you with this process. Please give me or Bryce a call
at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Ext 114 when you have plenty of time to review
this document in further detail. We are happy to answer any questions
you may have.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
In the case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, involving client Douglas Livers, an outstanding discovery matter was addressed in a pair of emails from The Whaley Law Firm. On Wednesday, October 30, 2024, at 1:18:25 PM Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Douglas Livers at douglivers@gmail.com with a cc to classyangel1984@yahoo.com. The message stated that the attached Defense Counsel’s Discovery Request had been previously sent to the Liverses on July 24, 2024, via USPS and email, and that they had not yet received any responses. The email emphasized that the discovery process is an imperative phase of litigation and that the responses were overdue by more than 60 days. It urged the Liverses to provide detailed answers so that the firm could finalize the discovery responses before the defense files a motion to compel or seeks penalties for the delay, and it offered to discuss any questions directly.

The email itemized seven discovery requests, asking for: 1) current occupation; 2) lost wages information; 3) whether any injuries were caused by an aggravation of a previous condition; 4) any jobs or tasks the client is unable to perform; 5) medical providers over the past 15 years; 6) employers over the last 10 years; and 7) any copies of repair bills or estimates. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, whose title is Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The contact numbers listed were D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, with a direct email address of Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a note indicating this is the new email address.

A separate morning communication to Douglas followed. It stated, “Good morning Douglas, Please find attached the Defense Counsel for Allstate Insurance’s Discovery Request propounded to you for your review and response.” The message acknowledged that the packet might seem overwhelming at first glance but reassured the client that the firm was available to assist with the process. It requested that Douglas call Sarena or Bryce at (502) 583-4022, extensions 104 or 114, when there was time to review the document in greater detail, and it offered to answer any questions. The sign-off again included Sarena M. Tuttle’s title and contact details, as well as the firm’s address and the directive to note the new email address.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

Client came in to go over Resp to DC Disc Req - Client mentioned he was on the clock at the time of the incident - WC aspect was never noted prior to this - Discussed w/BK - Feels its not worth pursuing though Client has not worked due to injury since Aug 22, 2023 - Reviewed medicals:

Nondisp fx of 4th metatarsal bone, l ft, 16 Jan, 2024
Effusion, left shoulder 16 Jan, 2024
Calcific tendinitis of left shoulder 16 Jan, 2024
Pain in left shoulder 28 Dec, 2023
Pain in left foot 28 Dec, 2023

The patient does not really have a history of left shoulder problems. He has had some knee problems in the past. He states that prior to the motor vehicle injury he was able to use the shoulder at a high demand without any difficulty.
End-stage left shoulder osteoarthritis exacerbated by a motor vehicle injury in January of 2023.

Pt is no longer working for the company he was working at time of the accident, pt was layoff about 6-7 months after the accident.
Pt has not been able to work due to pain. He will like to return to same line of work.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. The client came in to go over Resp to DC Disc Req. He noted that he was on the clock at the time of the incident. The workers’ compensation aspect was never noted prior to this. Discussed with BK; he feels it is not worth pursuing, although the client has not worked due to injury since August 22, 2023.

Medicals were reviewed and include: a nondisplaced fracture of the left fourth metatarsal bone (left foot) dated 16 January 2024; effusion of the left shoulder dated 16 January 2024; calcific tendinitis of the left shoulder dated 16 January 2024; pain in the left shoulder dated 28 December 2023; and pain in the left foot dated 28 December 2023. The patient does not have a meaningful history of left shoulder problems; he has had some knee problems in the past. He states that prior to the motor vehicle injury he was able to use the shoulder at a high demand without any difficulty. He has an end-stage left shoulder osteoarthritis that was exacerbated by a motor vehicle injury in January 2023.

The patient is no longer working for the company he was employed with at the time of the accident; he was laid off about 6–7 months after the accident. He has not been able to work due to pain and would like to return to the same line of work.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

about.relevance: workers' compensation aspect discussed and deemed not worth pursuing

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. In the matter of Douglas Livers v. Allstate, the Whaley Law Firm correspondence on November 20, 2024 reflects ongoing discovery issues and deposition scheduling for the client, Mr. Douglas Livers.

Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager with The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Ginny Donnell regarding the case. She noted that they still had not received your client’s responses to the discovery requests propounded to Allstate on July 23, 2024. Referring to a September conversation in which Mrs. Valerie W. Herbert asked them to “prove” that Defendant Lewis was uninsured, Tuttle stated that they had provided two denial letters showing Mrs. Lewis’s coverage had lapsed prior to the date of the incident and was not reinstated until after that date. She added that, at that time, they must await Allstate’s response to the Plaintiff’s first set of interrogatories before proceeding with deposition scheduling, and she requested any update on when those responses could be anticipated. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, who identified herself as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial (502) 357-9971; office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104; and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting that this is a new email address.

Earlier that same day, November 20, 2024, at 10:42?AM, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message chain. The forwarded message originated with Ginny Donnell, who dated the message as November 20, 2024 at 10:26?AM and addressed it to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. In her message, Donnell wrote: “Counsel, I am following up on Valerie’s email. Could you please provide dates for the deposition of Mr. Livers? Thank you.” She signed as Ginny Donnell, Legal Assistant to Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson, at TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, located at 11507 Main Street, Jefferson Marders Building, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243. She provided the firm’s phone number, (502) 245-7474, and fax number, (502) 245-7025, and listed the website www.thslaw.co.

The email chain included standard privileged and confidential notices. It stated that, unless otherwise indicated or obvious from the nature of the transmission, the information in the email was attorney privileged and confidential, intended for the named recipient, and that dissemination, distribution, or copying to others was strictly prohibited. If received in error or if the reader was not the intended recipient, the recipient was to notify the sender by telephone and delete the message. It also carried the disclaimer that there is no attorney–client relationship created by sending or receiving the email. The message further contained the firm’s warning that sending email does not establish an attorney–client relationship with the recipient, and that this firm acknowledges the disclaimer at www.thattorneys.com.

Additionally, the message included a tax-related disclaimer required by the IRS under Circular 230. It warned that, because the document does not contain all of the required disclosures, the recipient should not rely on any tax advice contained therein to avoid penalties, nor may any portion of the document be used in marketing or promotional materials.

The message concluded with the signature of Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the contact number 502-583-4022. The email chain also reflects the involvement of Valerie W. Herbert and Jennifer A. Peterson of TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN, PLLC, in the underlying deposition scheduling discussions.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ BK Sent over Resp to DC Disc Req - DC said he is not allowed to object to Request #18 (Medical Providers from last 15 yrs) - Advised BK Client stated in our meeting that he did not remember, does not have PCP, does not 'go to the doctor routinely' & did not have PHI hence gap in Tx - BK insists on Client Contact - States he does not believe Client has not been to the doctor in 15 yrs - Sent Text to S/O asking for any information her or Doug can remember - Awaiting Reply 

Good morning,
Bryce has reviewed and sent Doug's Responses to the Defenses Discovery Request to the Attorney. Unfortunately, the Defense is pushing for a list of the medical providers Doug seen in regards to his wrist & knee surgeries, is there any information you or Doug can provide as far as who he may have seen for them? I know he & I discussed it during our meeting and he could not recall at the time, however, any information as far as location or doctor would be most helpful to move things along. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 22 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023, Client: Douglas Livers.

On November 22, 2024, the client contact was initiated by Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm regarding the Douglas-Livers-MVA case. The notes indicate that BK sent over responses to the Defense Counsel’s Discovery Request (DC Disc Req). DC advised that he is not allowed to object to Request #18 (Medical Providers from last 15 yrs). It was advised that in a prior meeting, the client stated he did not remember, does not have a PCP, does not “go to the doctor routinely,” and did not have PHI, which created a gap in treatment. BK insists on client contact and states he does not believe the client has not been to the doctor in 15 years. BK also sent a text to S/O asking for any information she or Doug can remember. Awaiting reply.

Good morning, Bryce has reviewed and sent Doug’s responses to the Defense’s Discovery Request to the attorney. The defense, however, is pushing for a list of the medical providers Doug saw in relation to his wrist and knee surgeries, and is asking whether you or Doug can provide any information about who he may have seen for them. The note indicates that Doug and the speaker discussed this during the meeting and he could not recall at the time; nevertheless, any information regarding the location or the doctor would be most helpful to move things along. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

Person Making Contact: Sarena
Date & Time: November 22, 2024

episodes.original_body:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Response to 11.22 Contact:

Yes this is Doug Livers I'm returning a message regarding a message I received about past medical history in the last 10 years all my past Medical regarding my knee surgeries and carpal tunnel on both hands or all over 10 years ago and the last 10 years I have no medical history at all no appointments no surgeries no visits is it possible that I can set an appointment up to come back in speak in person about my case tomorrow if possible I feel it necessary after reading paperwork I received at my last visit I have some questions and more in depth information about quality of life since accident occurred I would greatly appreciate it
Posted by 5023853545 on 11/25/2024 at 12:14 PM

11/26: Sent to BK to call Client
11/26: BK Resp: If he wants to come in I'm happy to talk to him 

11/26: Sent Client Text on New #:
Good afternoon Doug,
Thank you for the response. What day works best for you to come in & sit down with Bryce?

Client Resp:
Tomorrow would be good if it works for everyone and thank you for your response I appreciate it

Reply to Client:
Awesome. Bryce does have a doctor's appointment in the afternoon but he could do 10am, does that work for you? 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 25 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023 involves client Douglas Livers. The note documents the client’s response to a prior contact dated November 22. In his message, Doug Livers states: “Yes this is Doug Livers I’m returning a message regarding a message I received about past medical history in the last 10 years all my past Medical regarding my knee surgeries and carpal tunnel on both hands or all over 10 years ago and the last 10 years I have no medical history at all no appointments no surgeries no visits is it possible that I can set an appointment up to come back in speak in person about my case tomorrow if possible I feel it necessary after reading paperwork I received at my last visit I have some questions and more in depth information about quality of life since accident occurred I would greatly appreciate it.” This message was posted by 5023853545 on 11/25/2024 at 12:14 PM.

On November 26, 2024, the note indicates that the message was sent to BK to call the client, and BK responded: “If he wants to come in I’m happy to talk to him.” Also on November 26, 2024, a text was sent to the client on a new number: “Good afternoon Doug, Thank you for the response. What day works best for you to come in & sit down with Bryce?” The client replied: “Tomorrow would be good if it works for everyone and thank you for your response I appreciate it.”

Following that exchange, the note records a reply to the client: “Awesome. Bryce does have a doctor’s appointment in the afternoon but he could do 10am, does that work for you?” The entry notes that the person making contact was Sarena, with the date and time listed as November 25, 2024.

Herbert of Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys emailed Sarena Tuttle and Ginny Donnell regarding deposition timing. In her message, Valerie stated that she could be available on February 4, 5, 6, 11, 12, 14, and 18, and asked them to confirm the deposition dates. If those dates did not work, she requested that they provide other dates, and she would arrange her schedule accordingly. Valerie signed the email with her contact information for Travis, Herbert & Stempien, located at 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, with a phone number of 502-245-7474 and a fax number of 502-245-7025, and her email address is vherbert@thattorneys.com. The message included the firm’s standard attorney-privilege and confidential information notices, stating the information is privileged and confidential for the intended recipient only and that dissemination to others is prohibited; it also carried the usual disclaimers about no attorney-client relationship being created by sending or receiving emails, and it included a tax-related Circular 230 warning regarding the limitations of tax advice in written communications. An embedded image reference appeared in the signature block.

Later that same day, at 3:50 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Ginny Donnell, cc’ing Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Valerie Herbert. She explained that they had received a CourtNet notification indicating your office filed a Notice to Take Deposition of their client, Douglas Livers, for January 31, 2025, but that date does not work for their office. She noted that she had not been cc’d on prior scheduling emails and requested that they provide new dates on which your office is available for the deposition. Sarena M. Tuttle's signature block identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct phone number was 502-357-9971, her office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and her email address was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a NEW email address.
