episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Douglas Livers v. Allstate (Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023), the deposition scheduling process generated a brief but important email exchange in December 2024 between The Whaley Law Firm and the office of Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys. The Whaley Law Firm represents Douglas Livers, and the deposition notice concerns Mr. Livers as the client.

On December 19, 2024, at about 3:50 PM, Sarena Tuttle, the Whaley Law Firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, sent an email to Ginny Donnell with copies to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Valerie Herbert, regarding the deposition scheduling for Douglas Livers. In that message, she noted that the CourtNet notification indicated the opposing side had filed a Notice to Take Deposition of their client for January 31, 2025. She explained that she had not been CC’d on the prior scheduling emails and that the January 31 date would not work for their office. She requested that the opposing side provide new dates on which they are available for the deposition.

Later that same day, Valerie Herbert of Travis, Herbert & Stempien replied. Her message stated that she could be available on February 4, 5, 6, 11, 12, 14, and 18. She asked to be updated to confirm the deposition, and she offered to adjust if those dates did not work by proposing other dates. Her contact information was provided as Valerie W. Herbert of Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys, with an office at 11507 Main Street in the Middletown Historic District of Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-245-7474 and fax 502-245-7025. The reply included the standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality notices, as well as disclaimers about no attorney-client relationship, and an IRS Circular 230 tax disclaimer, along with typical disclaimers about email communications and confidentiality.

This email chain also contains the background header information for the thread, including the subject “Douglas Livers v Allstate - Deposition Scheduling,” and the sender/recipient details. The thread reflects a prior message from Sarena Tuttle dated December 19, 2024 at 3:50 PM to Ginny Donnell and copied to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Valerie Herbert, with the subject noted above. In that earlier note, Sarena explained that a CourtNet notification had been received indicating a Notice to Take Deposition for January 31, 2025, and reiterated that the date did not work for their office, asking for new dates when the other side was available.

On December 20, 2024, at 9:37 AM, Sarena Tuttle followed up with a more definitive response to Valerie Herbert. She expressed appreciation for the quick reply and stated that the firm’s best available date is February 12. They could maintain a 10:00 a.m. start time, noted that Valerie’s office is a beautiful setting, and she intended to inform Mr. Livers that the date is confirmed. She closed by thanking Valerie and wishing happy holidays. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Contact numbers were listed as D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email was provided as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to acknowledge the new email address.

The correspondence reflects the procedural steps taken to schedule the deposition for Douglas Livers, including the initial objection to an January 31, 2025 date, Valerie Herbert’s proposed February dates, and the Whaley firm’s tentative confirmation of February 12 at 10:00 a.m. The exchange also records the involvement of the key participants: Sarena Tuttle (Whaley Law Firm), Ginny Donnell (on the opposing side’s office), Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon (Whaley Law Firm), and Valerie Herbert (Travis, Herbert & Stempien). The communications were accompanied by standard confidentiality and privilege notices, as well as a disclaimer regarding the absence of an attorney-client relationship and tax-related notices per Circular 230.

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on January 19, 2023, with Douglas Livers regarding a motor vehicle accident. The client indicated that the knee surgeries and carpal tunnel on both hands occurred more than ten years ago, and that in the last ten years he has had no medical history at all—no appointments, no surgeries, and no visits.

He asked whether it would be possible to schedule an appointment to return for an in-person discussion about his case, ideally tomorrow if possible. He noted that after reading the paperwork he received at his last visit, he has questions and would like more in-depth information about quality of life since the accident occurred. He would greatly appreciate it.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. This file concerns the motor vehicle accident case Livers v. Allstate, Jefferson County, case number 24-CI-004424, with the incident date referenced as January 19, 2023.

In a series of email exchanges during 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Valerie W. Herbert, an attorney with Travis, Herbert & Stempien, discussed potential settlement discussions for the case. The subject line across these exchanges was Livers v. Allstate (Jefferson 24-CI-004424). Bryce’s messages included the file’s Filevine project email address, DouglasLiversMVAZ4299598@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and the correspondence also cc’d Ginny Donnell and the Filevine project contact for the Livers matter.

The first outreach in the chain occurred on February 24, 2025, when Bryce emailed Valerie to inquire whether her office was interested in revisiting negotiations to resolve the matter. He stated that his office was open to informal discussions or mediation if needed and asked Valerie to let him know if he should resend the demand previously submitted to the adjuster. He closed with appreciation for a response and provided his firm’s contact information.

Valerie responded on March 3, 2025, telling Bryce that she would review her file and then give him a call to discuss.

On March 18, 2025, Bryce sent another follow-up message to Valerie, simply stating that he wanted to circle back on the matter. He again signed with his standard contact information and the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer that accompanies such emails.

Later that same day, Valerie replied. She explained that she had reached out to her adjuster about two weeks prior after her last email to discuss whether the adjuster believed there was enough information to schedule mediation now. Valerie noted that she had not heard back from the adjuster and said she would follow up with Bryce as soon as she spoke with her.

Finally, on April 2, 2025, Bryce sent a concluding follow-up: “Good afternoon counsel, Just following up. Any update is appreciated.” He again signed his name, provided his firm’s contact information, and included the standard attorney-client privilege notice.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications were accompanied by the usual confidentiality and privilege notices common to attorney correspondence, and the thread includes references to the case file’s Filevine project email address and the cc’d participants, including Ginny Donnell and the Douglas Livers MVA project address. The core facts preserved in these notes are that the parties were attempting to revisit settlement discussions, that Valerie intended to consult with her adjuster about scheduling mediation, and that as of April 2, 2025 there had been no communicated update from the adjuster.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. This matter concerns Livers v. Allstate in Jefferson County (case number 24-CI-004424), arising from a motor vehicle accident on January 19, 2023. In 2025, the counsel email communications reflect attempts to revisit settlement discussions and to move forward with discovery and mediation, depending on the assignment of a new adjuster.

On February 24, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Valerie Herbert, Esq., of Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys, to inquire whether her office was interested in revisiting negotiations to resolve the matter. He stated they were open to informal discussions or mediation if needed and asked Valerie to let him know if she would like him to resend the demand previously submitted to the adjuster; otherwise, he awaited her response. The message included the standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality notice typical for such emails.

Valerie Herbert replied on March 3, 2025, indicating she would review her file and then call Bryce to discuss the matter.

Later, on March 18, 2025, Bryce followed up again, sending a brief note stating, “Good morning counsel, just wanted to circle back on this one.” Valerie responded later that day, explaining that she had reached out to her adjuster about two weeks prior after her last email to determine whether the adjuster thought there was enough information to schedule mediation, but she had not yet heard back. She said she would follow up with Bryce as soon as she spoke with the adjuster.

There is another later communication dated April 21, 2025, in which Valerie advised Bryce that she had been told the adjuster working on the case with her had left Allstate, though she could not confirm this information yet. She stated that she wanted to mediate the case but could not move forward until a new adjuster was assigned. In the meantime, she planned to conduct some basic discovery and hoped to move ahead in 60 to 90 days. This message, like the others, included the standard attorney-privileged and confidential notices and disclaimers about attorney-client relationship and related IRS Circular 230 tax disclosures.

Valerie Herbert’s contact information appears in the signatures for the emails: TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN ATTORNEYS, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025; email Vherbert@thattorneys.com. Bryce Koon’s contact details as of these communications were The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The chain of communications confirms ongoing but unsettled efforts to schedule mediation and to progress discovery in a case concerning a 2023 motor vehicle accident, with the practical impediment being the assignment and status of the case’s adjuster at Allstate.

episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes a sequence of email communications regarding the case Livers v. Allstate (Jefferson 24-CI-004424) for client Douglas Livers, filed under the project name Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. The matter involves counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and the defense counsel at Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys. The July 7, 2025 email from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) to Valerie Herbert (and copied others, including Ginny Donnell and the Filevine project address DouglasLiversMVAZ4299598@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) began the latest follow-up, stating simply: “Good afternoon counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one. Any update appreciated.” The email included the firm’s standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimer, noting it was intended only for the named recipient and that no waiver of privilege should be assumed if received in error.

Earlier messages in the chain show ongoing discussions about mediation and the status of the adjuster handling the case. On April 21, 2025, Valerie Herbert of Travis, Herbert & Stempien Attorneys (11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025; vherbert@thattorneys.com) wrote that she had been told the adjuster working on the case had left Allstate, but she had not yet confirmed that information. She stated an intention to mediate the case but could not move forward until a new adjuster was assigned. In the meantime, she planned to conduct basic discovery and expressed hope that they could move ahead in 60 to 90 days. Her email included the standard attorney-privilege and confidential information notices, a no-attorney-client-relationship disclaimer, and other disclosures typical of correspondence from that firm.

In a prior exchange dated March 18, 2025, Valerie sent a message to Bryce Koon (with Ginny Donnell, Sarena Tuttle, and the Douglas Livers Filevine project address CC’d) regarding the same matter. In that message, she acknowledged Bryce’s email and said she had reached out to her adjuster about two weeks earlier after her last email to discuss whether the adjuster thought there was enough information to schedule mediation. Valerie stated she had not yet heard back from the adjuster and would follow up as soon as she spoke with her. This email also contained the standard attorney-privilege and confidential notices, the explicit disclaimer about no attorney-client relationship, and the Circular 230 tax-disclosure warnings.

Earlier still, on the same day (March 18, 2025) at 10:58 AM, Bryce had replied to Valerie with a brief note: “Good morning counsel, Just wanted to circle back on this one.” His message, like the others, was accompanied by the Whaley Law Firm signature block and the same confidentiality and privilege disclosures.

Across these communications, the central issues were consistent: confirming whether a new adjuster had been assigned so mediation could proceed, and whether mediation could be scheduled given the status of the adjuster and the ongoing discovery. The parties referenced a potential 60- to 90-day horizon for movement if the adjuster situation could be resolved and sufficient information gathered for mediation. The messages also repeatedly included standard privilege and confidentiality warnings and, in the March 18, 2025 emails, explicit notes that no attorney-client relationship is created by email exchanges.

In sum, the record shows a concerted but stalled effort to advance Livers v. Allstate toward mediation, contingent on confirmation of a new adjuster and the completion of basic discovery, with active follow-ups from both sides in March 2025 and a subsequent follow-up request from Bryce Koon in July 2025.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023. Client: Douglas Livers. This note concerns the Livers v. Allstate matter in Jefferson County (case number 24-CI-004424), arising from a motor vehicle accident on January 19, 2023. The current communication chain centers on mediation timing and adjuster assignment, with multiple emails exchanged between counsel.

On July 22, 2025, at 10:06:28 a.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Valerie Herbert, with Ginny Donnell copied and Douglas Livers MVA 1/19/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address included in the cc. The subject of the note was “Re: Livers v. Allstate (Jefferson 24-CI-004424).” In the body, Counsel stated that he was following up on the matter and thanked Valerie. His contact details were provided: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 365-5043; fax (502) 237-3207. The note also included the standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimer typical of electronic attorney correspondence, indicating that the message was intended only for the named recipient, that it may contain attorney-client privileged information, and instructions if the message was received in error. Additional disclaimers indicated that no waiver of privilege was intended and that the content should not be shared beyond the intended recipient.

This message followed a prior chain of emails. On July 7, 2025, Bryce Koon wrote to counsel with a concise follow-up: “Good afternoon counsel, Wanted to follow up on this one. Any update appreciated.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., with the same firm address and contact information as above, and the email carried the same standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

Earlier in the year, Valerie Herbert, of TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN ATTORNEYS, had provided an update regarding mediation prospects. On April 21, 2025 at 10:10 a.m. (Eastern), Valerie wrote that she had been told the adjuster working on the case with her had left Allstate, though she had not yet been able to confirm this definitively. She stated her intention to mediate the case but explained that she could not move forward until a new adjuster was assigned. In the meantime, she planned to conduct some basic discovery and anticipated progress within 60 to 90 days. Valerie included her firm’s contact information: TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN ATTORNEYS, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; phone (502) 245-7474; fax (502) 245-7025; email Vherbert@thattorneys.com. As with the other messages, the email contained extensive attorney-confidential-disclaimer language: that the information is attorney-privileged and confidential for the intended recipient, a reminder that the sender represents that no attorney-client relationship is established by sending or receiving the email, and that recipients should delete the message if it was received in error. The message also included the standard IRS Circular 230 warning about potential tax-related disclosures.

Additionally, Valerie’s March 18, 2025 email to Bryce Koon, dated 1:40 p.m., is part of the same thread. In that message, Valerie thanked Bryce for his prior email and reported that she had reached out to her adjuster about two weeks earlier to assess whether there was enough information to schedule mediation, but she had not heard back from the adjuster yet. She pledged to follow up as soon as she spoke with her, and she again provided her contact information: Valerie W. Herbert, TRAVIS, HERBERT & STEMPIEN ATTORNEYS, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; phone (502) 245-7474; fax (502) 245-7025; email Vherbert@thattorneys.com. This March 18 email also carried the same confidentiality and privilege notices, a no-attorney-client-relationship disclaimer, and the IRS Circular 230 tax-disclosure language.

In sum, the note records a sequence of communications from March through July 2025 between counsel for the plaintiff (Douglas Livers) and counsel for Allstate, focused on whether mediation could proceed given an unsettled adjuster assignment. Valerie Herbert indicated in March that she had not yet received a response from her adjuster after reaching out about mediation, and she planned to run basic discovery with an expected timeline of 60 to 90 days. In April, she reiterated that the adjuster had left Allstate and that mediation could not proceed without a new adjuster, while continuing discovery. Bryce Koon followed up in July with inquiries about any updates, and a final follow-up message from Bryce on July 22, 2025, reaffirmed the request for an update. All communications included their respective firm contact information and the customary confidentiality and privilege notices, along with disclosures related to attorney-client relationships and, in at least one email, the IRS Circular 230 warning. The case remains identified as Livers v. Allstate (Jefferson County, 24-CI-004424), with the client Douglas Livers and the related motor vehicle accident filing referenced as MVA 1/19/2023 and associated with the Filevine project email address listed in the cc field.

Case: Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023
Client: Douglas Livers

**FILE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED**

**Work Performed:** Comprehensive case file reorganization using 8-bucket system with parallel processing workflow.

**Results:**
- ✅ 264 files successfully organized and renamed (92% completion)
- ✅ Files categorized into proper buckets: Medical Records (80+ files), Litigation (85 files), Insurance (27 files), Lien (20 files), Client (20 files), Investigation (7 files), Negotiation Settlement (9 files)
- ✅ All organized files follow standardized naming convention: YYYY-MM-DD - Client Name - Category - Originator - Description
- ✅ Medical records organized by provider: Aptiva Health, Dixie Injury & Rehab, Aptiva Health Imaging
- ✅ Insurance files organized by type and carrier: BI/Root Insurance, PIP/Allstate, UIM/Allstate
- ✅ Lien files organized under Kentucky Child Support Enforcement
- ✅ Quality review completed with 1.5% error rate (3 errors corrected)

**Outstanding Items:**
- ⚠️ 23 files remain in root directory (not included in initial analysis phase)
- ⚠️ 15 court notification emails need renaming to standard format
- ⚠️ 5 image files in Review_Needed folder require manual categorization

**Key Findings from File Review:**
- Significant child support lien: $46,260.51 (Order to Withhold and Deliver dated 8/2/2024)
- Allstate Reservation of Rights letter dated 8/30/2025 citing coverage exclusions for employee use and workers' compensation
- Client deposition completed 2/12/2025
- Active mediation scheduling discussions with defense counsel (Valerie Herbert)
- Root Insurance BI coverage denied (policy lapsed at time of accident)

**Reports Generated:**
- File inventory: Reports/file_inventory_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md
- Reorganization map: Reports/file_reorganization_map_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md
- Quality review: Reports/quality_review_summary_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md
- Final summary: Reports/reorganization_summary_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md

**Next Steps:**
1. Complete organization of remaining 23 files in root
2. Rename court notification emails to standard format
3. Review and categorize 5 image files
4. Consolidate duplicate provider subdirectories
episodes.natural_language:
The case Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023 involves client Douglas Livers. The file organization task has been completed, with a comprehensive reorganization of the case files using an eight-bucket system and a parallel processing workflow.

Work performed and results: A total of 264 files were successfully organized and renamed, representing 92% completion. Files were categorized into the following buckets: Medical Records (80+ files), Litigation (85 files), Insurance (27 files), Lien (20 files), Client (20 files), Investigation (7 files), and Negotiation Settlement (9 files). All organized files follow the standardized naming convention: YYYY-MM-DD - Client Name - Category - Originator - Description. Medical records were organized by provider, specifically Aptiva Health, Dixie Injury & Rehab, and Aptiva Health Imaging. Insurance files were organized by type and carrier, including BI/Root Insurance, PIP/Allstate, and UIM/Allstate. Lien files were organized under Kentucky Child Support Enforcement. A quality review was completed with a 1.5% error rate, resulting in 3 errors corrected.

Outstanding items: 23 files remain in the root directory (not included in the initial analysis phase). Additionally, 15 court notification emails need renaming to the standard format, and 5 image files in the Review_Needed folder require manual categorization.

Key findings from file review: There is a significant child support lien for $46,260.51, based on an Order to Withhold and Deliver dated 8/2/2024. An Allstate Reservation of Rights letter dated 8/30/2025 cites coverage exclusions for employee use and workers' compensation. A client deposition was completed on 2/12/2025. Active mediation scheduling discussions are ongoing with defense counsel Valerie Herbert. Root Insurance BI coverage was denied due to the policy having lapsed at the time of the accident.

Reports Generated: The following reports were produced as part of the process: File inventory (Reports/file_inventory_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md), Reorganization map (Reports/file_reorganization_map_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md), Quality review (Reports/quality_review_summary_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md), and Final summary (Reports/reorganization_summary_Douglas-Livers-MVA-1-19-2023.md).

Next steps:
1. Complete the organization of the remaining 23 files in the root directory

4. Consolidate duplicate provider subdirectories
